moves.1. e4: I always favour 1.e4 as my opening, because I have little experience in 1.d4.
moves.1... e6: 1.e6 is common enough so that I know the main line for this, the French.
moves.2. d4: Following the main line of the French.
moves.2... c5: This move hit me like a bullet. I have never seen this move in play before. What I see way more often is 2...d5.
moves.3. Nf3: Although the d pawn was already protected, I protected it again with a knight while developing.
moves.3... Qa5+: The queen comes out with check, so I have to get out of it.
moves.4. Bd2: I block the check with the bishop, which attacks the offending queen.
moves.4... Qb6: The queen moves back and attacks the b pawn
moves.5. Be3: A mistake. Correct is Bc3, defending the b pawn.
moves.5... Qxb2: Black snaps at this opportunity to take my b pawn which I had missed. With this move, black attacks my rook in the corner.
moves.6. Nbd2: This was the only real way to get out of trouble because moving the knight to c3 would lose the knight...with check!
moves.6... Qc3: Black plays a move that keeps pressure on me to keep everything defended.
moves.7. Bc4: I am continuing development while black falls behind. I have developed all my minor pieces and ready to castle, while black only has his queen out.
moves.7... Qa5: Another queen move. Black should have been developing a longtime ago.
moves.8. O-O: I castle kingside and feel safe because the black queen will need time to get to my king, time that black needs to use developing his pieces.
moves.8... g6: This move prepares to fianchetto black's bishop which is currently being traped by the c5 pawn.
moves.9. Rb1: One of the advantages I get with black taking my b2 pawn is I get the half open b file whereas black doesn't have any files to work with his rooks.
moves.9... cxd4: Black trades his flank pawn with my center pawn while opening the 5th rank for his queen. However, I will maintain my center control because, as stated before, I have the lead in development.
moves.10. Bxd4: I take back with my bishop, and also force black to play f6, because 10...e5 fails to 11. Bxe5, 10...Nf6 fails to 11. Bxf6 and 10...Bg7 fails to 11.Bxg7.
moves.10... f6: The expected move. The pawn is protected by the knight on g8.
moves.11. e5: At this point I have high hopes of nabbing the rook on h8 and play 11.e5 to open up the long diagonal.
moves.11... f5: Good move. If black takes, then bishop takes back and I win material.
moves.12. Qe2: I put my queen on the same line as the king on e8 with hopes of a discovered attack on the king.
moves.12... d5: A big mistake. Do you remember en passant? I take the d pawn unleashing a discovered attack on the rook by my bishop followed by winning it. Notice at move 12, black has only moved his queen and pawns. Not a very good way to start a chess game and it cost black.
After this move, black , loses material. He will lose at least a rook.
moves.13... Bxd6: Black starts developing, finally, but it is too late. Loss of a rook is inevitable, so, in desperation, grabs a pawn to soften the material deficit.
moves.14. Bxh8: Now, I am free to nab the rook that I have been hoping to catch. Notice that my lead in development allowed me to win the rook.
moves.14... Nc6: Black tries in vain to catch up in developing, but he doesn't see that the e6 pawn is under-defended.
moves.15. Bxe6: I gain back the pawn I lost early on and threatening discovered check. The knight on g8 is also hanging.
moves.15... Nce7: A mistake which allows a further material deficit. Better was the other knight to e7.
moves.16. Bxg8: I can capture on g8 without problem because when I capture, I unleash my queen to pin the defender of the knight, allowing the free capture.
moves.16... Kd8: Black breaks the pin and now threatens my bishop. I have to move my light bishop...or do I?
moves.17. Bf6: I move my DARK squared bishop and pin the knight which was attacking my bishop. I add another attacker to the knight and hope to diminish blacks forces by adding pin after pin after pin.
moves.17... Ke8: This move does no good because the king walks into another pin by the queen so the bishop is in no danger.
moves.18. Bxe7: Up material, you trade pieces and that's what I am doing here.
moves.18... Bxe7: Black takes back and now the bishop is pinned.
moves.19... Qd8: To prevent further material loss, black protects the pinned bishop.
moves.20. Qe5: Advanding the queen forward so it can be more potent.
moves.20... Kf8: King attacks my bishop so I have to move it or defend it.
moves.21. Qh8: I defend the bishop with the queen and set up a discovered check.
moves.21... Ke8: If the king stayed where it was, it would be checkmate in one move.
moves.22. Be6+: A discovered check. There is only one reply.
moves.22... Bf8: Forced move. But now I win even more material.
moves.23. Bxc8+: Snagging the bishop. Black can't take because of a discovered check by the rook on e1.
moves.23... Qe7: This looks like a blunder but this is the best way to stave off mate. 23...Kf7 loses to 24. Rxb7+.
moves.24. Rxe7+: Winning the queen for the rook.
moves.25. Re1+: Now I bring my other rook in play and force mate in at most 4 moves.
moves.25... Kf7: Oops! This is the quickest way to lose.
moves.26. Ng5#: The knight comes into play and finishes off black with mate.
